content.prompt:
Why Study Newton Scooters?


YOUR GOAL is to build a scooter that can go farther than the rubber band car pictured below. Your scooter should look exactly like the one below except for ONE change that you think will improve the scooter's performance.

In this unit, you will design, build, and test a car. We will show you how to make a better scooter by thinking about energy, where it comes from and where it goes.


Master Scooter

Your Ideas About How Newton Scooters Work

 

Watch a video of a rubber band car!

Here are some other examples of Newton Scooters

  

  

A rubber band car is a type of Newton Scooter.

With materials right in your own home, you can build a Newton Scooter!  For each of the following write down your best ideas about what might affect how far a Newton Scooter might travel.

components.prompt: What are some factors that are important for a scooter to move?
How do you think the factors you listed in question 1 affect how a scooter moves?

components.html:
How Do Newton Scooters Work?

To help you make a good design choice, lets explore some important science concepts for Newton Scooters:

  • Potential Energy
  • Kinetic Energy
  • Thermal Energy

content.prompt:
A) Ramp Car

B) Spring Car

components.prompt: Where could you place the car on the ramp in Picture A to make the car go farther?
How could you change the spring in Picture B to make the car go farther?

content.prompt: Energy Graph

components.prompt: What does the graph tell you about potential energy?

content.prompt:
Testing a Newton Scooter

This first simulation is only supposed to be about potential energy.

components.prompt: What was the highest velocity recorded with this car?
How did moving the car along the ramp affect how your car traveled?
How did changing the spring affect how your car traveled?
Describe a similarity between where you placed the car on the ramp and how much the spring is squeezed.

content.prompt:
Potential Energy

 

Both the car on the ramp and the car with the spring have energy that is stored and available to do a task. We call this type of energy potential energy.

Other objects, like a bow and arrow, can also store potential energy.

components.prompt: Look at the archer above. How does his bow and arrow store potential energy?
What else can store potential energy like a bow and arrow. Explain.
If the car starts at the same height, what could you change about the scooter to make it go farther. Explain.
If the spring stays squeezed the same amount, what could you change about the scooter to make it go farther. Explain.

content.prompt: Energy Graph

components.prompt: What does the graph tell you about what happens to kinetic energy in the car?

nodes.title: Where is the wheel and axle?

content.prompt:
Where is the axle?

In the next simulation you will be able to adjust the friction between the axle and the car body.

The axle is the rod that passes through the wheels.

Testing a Newton Scooter

In the second run students will be able to change sliders for the size of scooter body and for friction between the wheel and axle.The ramp height and spring compression should be constant.

This second simulation is supposed to be about kinetic energy.

There will also be position/time graphs and/or potential/kinetic/thermal energy graphs below the simulation

components.prompt: What was the highest velocity recorded with this car?
Which variable(s) affects how far the car traveled?
Describe how the variable(s) you chose above work the same or differently for the ramp and the spring.
Using evidence from the above graph, how are potential and kinetic energy related?

content.prompt:
Converting Potential Energy to Kinetic Energy

Kinetic energy is MOVEMENT energy.

When the car starts moving, potential energy becomes kinetic energy.

components.prompt: How is potential energy turned into kinetic energy in the bow and arrow?
What else can change potential energy into kinetic energy like the bow and arrow? Explain.

content.prompt:
What else happens to kinetic energy?

Friction happens when two objects rub against each other. When there is friction, heat is released. This heat is called thermal energy.

When there is friction, kinetic energy becomes thermal energy over time.

components.prompt: What would happen if there were no friction in the scooter?

nodes.title: Law of the Conservation of Energy

content.prompt:
Law of the Conservation of Energy

 

Potential Energy + Kinetic Energy + Thermal Energy = Total Energy

Energy is not lost or created. It is either stored or transformed. This is called the law of the conservation of energy.

 

Energy Graph

components.prompt: Using evidence from the graph, what is the relationship between kinetic energy and thermal energy?
How does the graph support the law of the conservation of energy?

components.html:
The Master Scooter Races!


Now that we know about how energy is stored and how it creates movement, let's find out how the Master Scooter performed.

We tested the Master Scooter 3 times. The results are in the following steps.

The scooter's best distance is the distance you will need to beat!

components.prompt:
Testing the Master Scooter

 

The master scooter had 3 test trials.

In the first test, the stop watch was running for 10 seconds.

  • The scooter began the race at the 0 meter mark.
  • At 2 seconds the scooter had reached 1.0 meters
  • At 5 seconds it reached 1.5 meters.
  • The scooter didn't move anymore during the 10 second trial.

Draw a graph to represent the scooters performance.
components.title: Master Scooter's 1st Test Run

content.prompt:
Does your graph look like the Master Scooter graph?

Click Make a change to go back and improve your graph.

import previous work.

Make a change

components.prompt: What do you need to change to make your prediction graph look like the Master Scooter graph?

Testing the Master Scooter

 

In the second test, the stop watch was running for 15 seconds.

  • The scooter began the race at the 0 meter mark.
  • At 5 seconds the scooter had reached 1.2 meters
  • At 5 seconds the scooter hit a rock in its path and started going backward.
  • At 9 seconds the scooter had moved back to 1 meter.
  • The scooter didn't move anymore during the 15 second second trial.

Draw a graph to represent the scooters performance.
components.title: Master Scooter's 2nd Test Run

content.prompt:
Does your prediction graph look like the Master Scooter graph?

Click Make a change to go back and improve your graph.

import previous work.

Make a change

components.prompt: What do you need to change to make your prediction graph look like the Master Scooter graph?

Testing the Master Scooter

 

In the third test, the stop watch was running for 20 seconds.

  • The scooter began the race at the 0 meter mark.
  • The rubber band was stuck on part of the axle and unwound slowly. By 9 seconds the scooter had reached 1 meter.
  • At 9 second seconds the rubber band came free and the scooter sped up and reached 1.8 meters at 13 seconds.
  • The scooter didn't move anymore during the 20 second second trial.

Draw a graph to represent the scooters performance.
components.title: Master Scooter's 2nd Test Run

content.prompt:
Does your prediction graph look like the Master Scooter graph?

Click Make a change to go back and improve your graph.

import previous work.

Make a change

components.prompt: What do you need to change to make your prediction graph look like the Master Scooter graph?

components.html:
What question do you want to investigate?


Your challenge is to beat the Master Scooter's best distance: 1.8 m.

You will be investigating ONE variable to make your scooter different than the Master Scooter. Below are some ideas you can investigate or you can pick one of your own.

  • How will your scooter store potential energy?
  • How much friction is in the wheel and axle?
  • What size is the scooter body?
  • Is there another factor you think would make your scooter go a farther distance?

components.prompt:
In this step you will label parts of the master scooter.

Use the labels on the left to get you started. Use the "New Label" button to create new labels for any other parts you think are important.

content.prompt:
Design Your Own Newton Scooter!

Now choose the variable you think will help your scooter to beat the Master!

Your scooter should look exactly like the scooter below except for the variable you choose to test.

components.prompt: What variable would your group like to test?

choices.text: friction between the wheels and axles
other (be sure to say which variable you choose in the box below)

components.prompt: How will the variable you change be different than the Master Scooter?
Why do you think your change will make your scooter better than the Master Scooter?

Using the draw tools, sketch a design of your Newton Scooter.

Be sure to label all of the important parts.

components.html: can students load the annotator image of the master scooter and their drawing and annotate their drawing next to the annoted master scooter?

content.prompt: Materials List

components.prompt: In the space below, list what materials you will be using to construct your Newton Scooter.

components.html:
Start Building Your Newton Scooter!


Now that you've designed your Newton Scooter, it's time to build it! Gather all of your materials and start building!

components.prompt:
Testing Your Scooter

 

How do you think your scooter will perform?

Predict your scooter's performance on the graph below.
components.title: Your Scooter

content.prompt:
Predict Your Scooter's Performance

repopulate with prediction and best master scooter graph

components.prompt: Using evidence from your prediction graph, how will the variable you change help you beat the Master Scooter?

components.html:
Test Your Newton Scooter! 

Can you beat the Master?


  1. Take one computer to the testing station.
  2. Test your Newton Scooter using the motion sensors!
  3. Record the time and distance your scooter travels.

components.prompt:
GRAPH YOUR DATA

The motion sensor software allows you to export data as a "csv" file. Talk to your teacher about how to do this. When this file is on your computer, pick your best run and click Import Data below and select the file. When you see the graph answer the questions below.
(Put Table in this step, too) How does your scooter compare to the Master Scooter? Use evidence from the graph to support your answer.

content.prompt:
Reflecting on Your Scooter

repopulate with test data (graph and table??)

components.prompt: Using evidence from the graph or table, what does your scooter's performance tell you about your scooter's potential energy?
Using evidence from the graph or table, what does your scooter's performance tell you about your scooter's kinetic energy?

content.prompt:
What other types of energy can we test?

 

Testing the whole scooter gives us some information, but we can still learn more.

By using a ramp we can test the friction of your scooter. No need to wind up your rubber band or blow up a balloon, your scooter is only going to use gravity as a power source this time.

components.prompt: You will be comparing your scooter's performance to the Master Scooter's performance on the ramp. What type(s) of energy are you comparing with the set-up above?
How does using the ramp and not your power source help us understand how your scooter uses energy?

Use the ramp to test out how far your car can move without the elastic power source.
  1. Place your scooter at the top of the ramp and let it slide down.
  2. Measure the distance from the bottom of the platform to where your scooter stops.

What is your friction score? Based on how far your scooter traveled, find your score below.

1: 20-100 cm (low friction)
2: 10-20 cm (medium friction)
3: 5-10cm (high friction)
4: 0-4cm (very high friction)
Using evidence from the table, how does your scooter's friction differ from the Master Scooter's friction?

content.prompt:
Reflecting on Your Scooter

repopulate with friction data

components.prompt: What does comparing your friction score to the Master Scooter's score tell you about how your scooter uses energy?
How would you change your scooter's friction to go the same distance as the master scooter?

nodes.title: Take a picture and critique your Newton Scooter

components.prompt:
1. Take a picture of your Newton Scooter and upload it here.

2. Underneath your picture answer these 2 questions (can we just ask students to paste their responses from the Collect data step and/or friction step?):

  1. Did your scooter perform better than the Master Scooter?
  2. What evidence do you have to support your response to question 1?

3. Press SAVE!

4. Take a look at other groups' responses to see who beat the Master's distance!
What evidence do other teams have that they beat the master?
Based on the evidence, what should you change about your scooter to improve its performance?

choices.text: friction between the wheel and axle
other variable (be sure to mention what variable below)

components.prompt: Explain how changing the variable(s) you chose above will improve a scooter's performance.

content.prompt:
Below is a graph of the Master Scooter's energy during its best test.

Energy Graph

components.prompt: Based on the variable you tested, what type of energy did you expect to affect?
Explain how the energy graph of your scooter would look different than the graph above.

content.prompt: Improvements

components.prompt: If you were able to re-build your scooter, what changes would you make?
How would these changes affect your scooter's performance? Be sure to discuss potential energy, kinetic energy, and/or thermal energy.
